scenes.plot_segment: A character narrates about 'the game' of surgery, stating that people either have what it takes or they don't. The narrator mentions their mother was one of the greats, but feels personally unprepared.

In a house, two unidentified people have an awkward morning conversation. One says the situation is humiliating and insists the other must leave because they are late for their first day of work. They discuss whether one of them lives there, revealing it was their mother's house and is being sold. The conversation turns awkward when one assumes the mother is dead, but she is not. They agree not to exchange personal details. The person going to shower says goodbye, and the other introduces himself as Derek. The first person is called Meredith. They say goodbye.

A group of new surgical interns gathers at the hospital. An authoritative voice addresses them, explaining that they are now doctors, not students, and that the next seven years will be both the best and worst of their lives. The speaker warns that many will not make it through the program. The narrator again states they feel unprepared.

In a hospital corridor, several interns, including Christina, George, and others, discuss the small number of women in their group and rumors about one being a model. They compare which resident they are assigned to, mentioning 'Bailey' and referring to her as 'the Nazi.' George introduces himself and recalls meeting someone at a mixer. The group is called by name: O'Malley, Yang, Gray, Steven.

The interns observe Dr. Bailey, surprised that she is a woman. They speculate about her nickname and whether she is nice. Izzy introduces herself as Isabelle Stevens. Dr. Bailey lays out five strict rules for the interns, emphasizing discipline, hard work, and not waking her unless a patient is dying. She assigns tasks and tells them their first shift is 48 hours. She instructs them to follow her every move.

A medical emergency is announced: Katie Bryce, a 15-year-old girl, is brought in with seizures. Dr. Bailey and Dr. Burke lead the team. Bailey assigns Christina to labs, George to patient workups, and Meredith to take Katie for a CT scan, making Katie Meredith's responsibility. Izzy is told to perform rectal exams.

In a hospital area, an unidentified person asks another what they are doing there. Someone reports that Katie Bryce's labs are clear, with no explanation for her seizures. They mention a rumor that the best intern is allowed to perform a procedure during the first shift. The other person tells them to leave.

A patient jokes about their upcoming bypass surgery and dietary restrictions. An intern reassures the patient about Dr. Burke's skills. Another character gets lost in the hospital and is told so. The intern checks on Katie, who is upset about missing her pageant, the Spokane Teen Miss, where she was a top contender. Katie is frustrated and asks if the intern is new.

Izzy prepares to perform a rectal exam on a patient. Katie talks about twisting her ankle during talent rehearsal for rhythmic gymnastics and complains about being stuck with a clueless person. Katie says she and the intern will have fun together.

In a break area, interns discuss the difficulty of their shift. One says they can't eat after performing 17 rectal exams and feels disliked by Dr. Bailey. The group gossips about Meredith, revealing her mother is Ellis Gray, a renowned surgeon. They discuss Ellis Gray's achievements. Someone complains about Katie Bryce being difficult. Dr. Bailey arrives and announces that the honor of performing the first surgery goes to the intern who shows the most promise. George O'Malley is chosen to scrub in for an appendectomy.

Two doctors discuss George O'Malley's selection. One doubts George's abilities, saying he barely made the program. The other insists George is their pick, explaining that picking one intern to 'terrorize' helps the others fall in line. Katie Bryce's room is mentioned. Katie's parents arrive, worried about her condition and possible surgery. An intern, unsure, says they are not Katie's doctor and goes to find the attending.

An intern asks another about who should talk to Katie's parents. They are told Dr. Shepherd is now Katie's attending. Meredith approaches Dr. Shepherd, who is revealed to be Derek from the earlier scene. They awkwardly discuss their previous night together and agree that their relationship cannot continue now that he is her attending. Meredith insists on professionalism.

In the operating gallery, interns watch George O'Malley prepare for surgery. They bet on whether he will succeed or fail. George begins the appendectomy under supervision. He successfully removes the appendix but then tears the cecum, causing bleeding. The supervising doctor takes over, calling George a 'pansy-ass idiot.' The other interns nickname George '007,' meaning 'license to kill.'
George, upset, confronts his peers about being called '007.' They deny it, but he is unconvinced. Suddenly, there is an emergency call for Katie Bryce. The interns rush off.

Interns lament the difficulty of surgery and joke about geriatrics being easier. One says they need to get their own place. In another area, an intern is paged 911 for Katie Bryce but finds Katie is just bored and wants to watch her pageant on TV. The intern tells Katie to stop wasting their time and go to sleep.

An intern asks another for help starting a central line for Mr. Jones, but admits never having done one. They consider asking Dr. Bailey, but hesitate. Eventually, Dr. Bailey is approached and, annoyed, tells them not to bother her unless the patient is dying. Later, Dr. Bailey warns that next time she is woken, the patient better be near death.

A nurse suggests a patient may not have pneumonia. An intern dismisses the nurse and orders antibiotics. Another intern, Alex, introduces himself and makes a derogatory comment about nurses. Izzy confronts him for calling her a nurse. Alex asks about another intern, showing interest. His friend tells him to stop talking.

Katie Bryce has multiple grand mal seizures. Dr. Bailey asks Meredith how to proceed. Meredith lists the medications given. Lorazepam and phenobarbital are administered with no effect. Katie's heart stops. The team performs defibrillation and revives her after several attempts. Dr. Bailey scolds Meredith for not paging her immediately and reminds her that if someone dies, it's Bailey's responsibility.

Katie's parents confront Dr. Shepherd, frustrated that there is still no diagnosis. Dr. Shepherd admits he does not know the cause yet. Mr. Bryce demands another doctor. Dr. Shepherd assures them he is working hard. In another room, a patient is told about bypass surgery and reassured by an intern. The patient's spouse is promised that everything will be fine. Dr. Burke later admonishes the intern for making promises, saying only God can guarantee outcomes, and instructs the intern to tell the spouse about the patient's death.

In a break room, an intern sutures a banana to stay awake. Another apologizes for being mean when tired. The group wonders why they are called in. Dr. Shepherd arrives and asks the interns for help diagnosing Katie Bryce, offering the incentive of scrubbing in on her surgery to whoever finds the answer. Dr. Bailey hands out Katie's chart.

An intern pages Dr. Bailey about a patient still short of breath. Bailey dismisses the concern, saying the patient is old and to stop paging her. Another intern asks Meredith to work together on Katie's case, offering her the surgery if they succeed. Meredith agrees, saying she doesn't want to spend time with Dr. Shepherd. Christina asks why, and Meredith confides that she slept with him. They continue to review Katie's case, ruling out various diagnoses.

Christina asks Meredith if Dr. Shepherd was good in bed. They discuss Katie's lack of chance to become a person if she dies. Meredith suddenly realizes something about Katie's rhythmic gymnastics talent and her recent fall. Meredith and Christina rush to Dr. Shepherd, proposing that Katie may have a subarachnoid hemorrhage caused by a minor fall. Dr. Shepherd is skeptical but orders further investigation.

Dr. Shepherd and the interns review Katie's scans and find a minute subarachnoid hemorrhage, confirming the diagnosis. Dr. Shepherd praises Meredith and Christina for their work and tells Meredith she will scrub in on the surgery.
Christina is disappointed not to be chosen for the surgery. Meredith reflects on the unpredictability of life and the importance of seizing opportunities.

Dr. Burke informs an intern that the bypass patient died due to heart damage. The intern is upset, having promised the patient's wife he would be fine. Dr. Burke reprimands the intern for making promises and instructs them to tell the spouse about the death. The intern delivers the news to Gloria, who is devastated.

Izzy prepares Katie for surgery, joking about making her look cool as a bald beauty queen. Meredith asks Dr. Shepherd if she was chosen for the surgery because they slept together. He jokes 'yes,' then clarifies she earned it. Meredith says Christina should take her place, but Dr. Shepherd insists Meredith should follow the case through. He encourages her not to let their personal history interfere with her opportunity.

George and another intern talk about their parents' expectations and the pressure of being a surgeon. George recalls his mother doubting his abilities. They agree that being seen as a superhero sounds good. They wonder if they will survive the program.

A supervising doctor quizzes an intern about a patient with post-op fever. The intern struggles to answer. Another intern correctly lists the five Ws of post-op fever. The supervisor points out that pneumonia is often assumed without proper testing. The correct diagnosis is suggested to be a pulmonary embolus, and the intern is instructed to follow the recommended procedures. The supervisor recognizes Meredith as Ellis Gray's daughter and welcomes her.

Dr. Shepherd gathers the surgical team, declaring it a beautiful night to save lives. He encourages the team to have fun. The narrator reflects on the challenges of being a surgeon, the weight of responsibility, and the love of the work. Meredith and Christina agree not to have an emotional conversation and tease each other about their appearance.
In the OR, an intern expresses excitement after assisting in surgery, describing it as a high better than drugs. Meredith and Christina share a moment of satisfaction and accomplishment.

Meredith narrates that she and the other interns survived their first shift. She reflects on her colleagues, saying she likes them and decides not to sell her mother's house, planning to get roommates instead.
Meredith visits her mother in a care facility. Her mother does not recognize her and says she used to be a doctor. Meredith gently reminds her mother that she was a surgeon.
